questions.text:
Assertion: Hot flushes are common after menopause

Reason: Estrogen withdrawal happens in menopause
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menopause

 

Menopause is defined as the cessation of ovarian function resulting in permanent amenorrhea. It takes 12 months of amenorrhea to confirm that menopause has set in.

 

Hot flushes

  • Most common symptom experienced
  • Hot flushes are the waves of vasodilation affecting face and neck lasting for 2-5 minutes followed by profuse sweating
  • Occur throughout the day, but severe at night
  • Symptoms – headache, palpitations, anginal pain 
  • Cause: Oestrogen deficiency – reduces hypothalamic endorphins which release more norepinephrine and serotonin – inappropriate heat loss mechanism

 

1. Lifestyle and Behavioral Measures (First-line for Mild Symptoms)

 

  • Wear light, layered clothing
  • Avoid triggers: spicy food, caffeine, alcohol, hot beverages
  • Maintain a cool environment
  • Stress reduction techniques: yoga, mindfulness, CBT
  • Regular exercise

 

2. Hormonal Therapy (Most Effective for Moderate to Severe Symptoms)

 

A. Estrogen Therapy

 

  • Indicated for moderate-to-severe hot flushes
  • Most effective treatment
  • Given as systemic estrogen (oral/transdermal)
  • If uterus is intact, must be combined with progestogen to prevent endometrial hyperplasia

 

B. Combined Estrogen + Progestogen Therapy

 

  • Indicated for women with a uterus
  • Reduces vasomotor symptoms while protecting the endometrium

 

C. Tibolone

 

  • Synthetic steroid with estrogenic, progestogenic, and androgenic properties
  • Effective for hot flushes, mood, and libido

 

D. Transdermal Estrogen

 

  • Preferred in women with risk of VTE or liver disease
  • Bypasses first-pass metabolism

 

3. Non-Hormonal Pharmacologic Options

 

Recommended for women who cannot take hormones (e.g., history of breast cancer, VTE)

 

 

4. Complementary and Alternative Therapies

 

(Evidence is limited and mixed)

 

  • Isoflavones (soy, red clover): Phytoestrogens; mild benefit
  • Black cohosh: Mixed evidence
  • Acupuncture: Some women report benefit

 

5. Newer Therapies

 

  • Fezolinetant (Neurokinin 3 receptor antagonist)
    • FDA-approved nonhormonal drug for moderate-to-severe vasomotor symptoms
    • Targets hypothalamic thermoregulation

 

Ref: Page 55, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: Atrophic vaginitis
Lichen planus
Lichen sclerosis
Recurrent cervical cancer

questions.text: A 48y woman comes to the clinic due to dyspareunia which has worsened over the last 4 months. Five years ago, she underwent chemoradiation for stage 2 cervical cancer. She has only recently resumed sexual activity after a gap of about 5 years. Despite over the counter use of lubricants, she is till having pain. There is no postcoital bleeding. She is amenorrhoeic since the chemoradiation. On examination, the vaginal introitus is narrow and the vagina is pale. The cervix appears scarred but there is no growth or ulcer and does not bleed on touch. What is the likely cause of her dyspareunia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Atrophic Vaginitis

  • This patient has atrophic vaginitis which is part of genitourinary syndrome of menopause
  • This is due to medically induced menopauses (post CT/RT)
  • Estrogen maintains the moisture, blood flow and collagen content of vulvo vaginal tissue and hypo-estrogenism (menopause) causes dryness and decreased elasticity in these tissues.

Other Options:

  • Option B: Lichen planus (LP): LP is a complex immunologic disease mediated by cytotoxic T-cells directed against basilar keratinocytes.The disease produces symptoms of soreness, burning, pain, pruritus, contact/post-coital bleeding, dyspareunia, discharge,
  • Option C: Lichen sclerosis: ​​​​​​​Vulvar lichen sclerosus (VLS) is a chronic inflammatory dermatosis characterized by ivory-white plaques or patches with glistening surface commonly affecting the vulva and anus. Common symptoms are irritation, soreness, dyspareunia, dysuria, and urinary or fecal incontinence.
  • Option D: Recurrent cervical cancer: ​​​​​​​This would present as vaginal bleeding or a foul smelling disharge

Educational Objective:

  • Estrogen maintains the moisture, blood flow and collagen content of vulvo vaginal tissue and hypo-estrogenism  (menopause) causes dryness and decreased elasticity in these tissues
  • HRT is indicated in women who have symotoms of vaginal dryness in the menopause

choices.text: Oligomenorrhea
Hypomenorrhea
Menorrhagia
Polymenorrhea

questions.text: Which of these is seen in Asherman syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hypomenorrhea

  • Asherman’s syndrome (intra-uterine synechiae) is more common with secondary amenorrhea or hypomenorrhea.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Oligomenorrhoea (infrequent cycles): This is seen in anovular cycles like PCOS
  • Option C: Menorrhagia: This is heavy bleeding and is seen in fibroids, adenomyosis, Copper containing IUD 
  • Option D: Polymenorrhoea: This is frequent cycles and is seen in PID, thyroid disorders and in short luteal phase

Educational Objective:

Asherman Syndrome 

  • This is intrauterine synechiae
  • Occurs due to: 
    • Endometrial or cervical scarring (e.g. vigorous curettage)
    • Infections – due to intrauterine device, tuberculosis, schistosomiasis
    • Severe pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • C/F: HYpomenorrhoea or secondary amenorrhoea, infertility
  • Diagnosis:
    • HSG: Irregular uterine cavity on HSG (moth eaten appearance)
    • Hysteroscopy: Ix of choice: Adhesions are seen in the uterine cavity
  • Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

choices.text: It is effective for vasomotor symptoms during perimenopausal period
It should be given for young women with premature menopause
It is useful for primary prevention of heart disease
Cyclical HRT is preferred over continuous HRT in perimenopausal women

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding Hormone Replacement Therapy in menopause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is useful for primary prevention of heart disease

Other Options

  • Option A: It is effective for vasomotor symptoms during perimenopausal period: The most common indication for HRT is vasomotor symptoms in the peri menopausa/ menopause
  • Option B: It should be given for young women with premature menopause: Women who ave premature menopause (menopsuae < 40y) should be started on HRT
  • Option D: Cyclical HRT is preferred over continuous HRT in perimenopausal women: Cyclical HRT will ensure the patient gets regular cycles alongwith treating her symptoms in peri-menopausal women, Women who are post menopause are given continuous HRT to ensure amenorrhoea. 

Educational Objective:

Hormone Replacement Therapy

Indications of HRT

  • Relief of vasomotor symptoms
  • Prevention of osteoporosis
  • To maintain the quality of life in menopausal years
  • Premature ovarian failure
  • Gondal dysgenesis
  • Surgical or radiation menopause

**Although HRT may be cardio protective, it is not given for prevention as the risks outweight the benefits

CONTRAINDICATIONS TO HRT

  • Undiagnosed genital tract bleeding
  • Estrogen dependent neoplasm in the body
  • History of venous thromboembolism
  • Active liver disease
  • Gallbladder disease

MONITORING PRIOR TO AND DURING HRT

A base level parameter of the following and their subsequent check up (at least annually) are mandatory.

  • Physical examination including pelvic examination.
  • Blood pressure recording.
  • Breast examination and Mammography.
  • Cervical cytology
  • Pelvic ultrasonography (TVS) to measure endometrial thickness (normal <5 mm).

Any irregular bleeding should be investigated thoroughly (endometrial biopsy, hysteroscopy).

Ideal serum level of estradiol should be 100 pg/ml during HRT therapy. Serum level of estradiol is useful to monitor the HRT therapy rather than that of serum FSH.

questions.text: A 15y girl with primary amenorrhea is diagnosed to have Turner Syndrome. What Hormone replacement therapy should be given?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Growth hormone + E + P

45XO is suggestive of Turners syndrome

Hormone Replacement in Turner Syndrome

  • Growth hormone (GH) therapy has become the standard of care for girls with Turner Syndrome and should be considered as soon as decreased linear growth velocity is apparent.
  • Final adult height is maximized if GH therapy is begun at a young age; and is positively associated with the duration of treatment.
  • Recent studies have suggested that treatment initiated prior to 4 years of age significantly improved height outcome.
  • Most girls with Turner require hormone replacement therapy for breast development, uterine growth, and bone health.
  • The consensus is to initiate hormone replacement therapy at a time that coincides with normal female pubertal development.
  • Initial hormone replacement involves low dose estrogen monotherapy. Progestogen replacement is generally added 1–2 years after starting estrogen or upon breakthrough bleeding.

Educational Objective: 

  • Most girls with Turner require hormone replacement therapy for breast development, uterine growth, and bone health.
  • The consensus is to initiate hormone replacement therapy at a time that coincides with normal female pubertal development.
  • Initial hormone replacement involves low dose estrogen monotherapy. Progestogen replacement is generally added 1–2 years after starting estrogen or upon breakthrough bleeding.

Educational Objective:

Causes of postmenopausal bleeding

  • Abnormal perimenopausal and postmenopausal bleeding should always be taken seriously and be properly investigated.
  • Invasive tumors of the cervix, vagina and vulva are usually evident on local and Speculum examination and any lesion identified should be biopsied.
  • If any visible cervical growth à biopsy ¡s taken for histology.
  • If cervix apparently looks normal à cervical and endocervical smear to exclude dysplasia or CIN.
  • The possibility of uterine source of bleeding must always be eliminated.

choices.text: Transvaginal ultrasound
Perform endometrial ablation
Stop the estrogen patch and place an LNG-IUD
Schedule a hysterectomy

questions.text: A 54y woman presents to the OPD with several months of irregular vaginal spotting. She does not give a history of heavy bleeding but only that her undergarments are stained with blood. She attained menopause at the age of 52 and she had hot flushes and night sweats for which she was started on the transdermal estrogen patch and progesterone only pills. She has been consistently using the estrogen patches but stopped the progesterone in view of severe nausea. She has no significant medical history. She is on regular HPV screening and her last HPV was done 2 year earlier which was normal. Speculum exam reveals a normal cervix and vagina with minimal blood in the upper vagina. Bimanual exam reveals a small uterus with no adnexal mass. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transvaginal ultrasound

  • The probable cause of this patients bleeding is endometrial atrophy/ malignancy due to unopposed estrogen
  • She requires a Transvaginal scan to see the endometrial thickness and if > 5mm, an endometrial biopsy should be done
  • HRT in women with a uterus should always be given Estrogen + Progesterone as Estrogen alone can lead to endometrial hyperplasia
  • In hysterectomized women, Estrogen alone can be given

Other Options

  • Option A: Perform endometrial ablation: Without knowing the cause of bleeding, ablation will not be done. Endometria ablation is done in women with AUB where malignancy has been excluded
  • Option B: Stop the estrogen patch and place an LNG-IUD: Estrogen is the treatment for hot flashes. Progesterone is added to prevent endometrial hyperplasia and malignancy. Simply putting an LNG-IUD will not solve her problems and without ruling out atypia or malignancy, LNG-IUD cannot be put.
  • Option C: Schedule a hysterectomy: A hysterectomy is done only if there is endometrial atypia or malignancy. 

Educational Objective: 

  • HRT in women with a uterus should always be given Estrogen + Progesterone as Estrogen alone can lead to endometrial hyperplasia
  • In hysterectomized women, Estrogen alone can be given

choices.text: Bisphosphonates
Calcium + Vitamin D supplementation
Estrogen + Progesterone
Teriparatide

questions.text: A 60y woman presents for a routine checkup. She has a sedentary lifestyle and her BMI is 26. She used to smoke 1 pack/ day but has recently stopped. She was advised calcium and vitamin D supplementation at her last checkup but has not been taking these. She has no significant medical history. A DEXA scan is done which shows her T score as -2.5. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bisphosphonates

  • A T score of > -2.5 is indicative of Osteoporosis
  • As she also has several risk factors (postmenopausal, h/o smoking, not taking ca and vit D), she is at an increased risk of fractures
  • The drug of choice for treatment of Osteoporosis is Bisphosphonates

Other Options: 

  • Option B: Calcium and vit D should also be advised to all post-menopausal women so although this option is correct too, a better option is bisphosphonates
  • Option C: HRT (e + P) can be given to prevent Osteoporosis but is not the 1st line drug of choice
  • Option D: Teriparatide is recombinant parathormone and is given in women who have not responded to bisphosphonates.

Educational Objective: 

The drug of choice for treatment of Osteoporosis is Bisphosphonates

choices.text: Delay in return of fertility after contraception
Sheehan syndrome
Premature ovarian failure
Secondary amenorrhea due to hypothyroidism

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman complains that she has not had a period for 3 months. Four home pregnancy tests have all been negative. She started her periods at the age of 15 years and until 30 years she had a normal 28-day cycle. She had one daughter by normal delivery 2 years ago, following which she breast-fed for 6 months. After that she had normal cycles again for several months and then her periods stopped abruptly. She was using the progesterone only pill for contraception while she was breastfeeding and stopped 6 months ago as she is keen to have another child. She reports symptoms of dryness during intercourse and has experienced sweating episodes at night as well as episodes of feeling extremely hot at any time of day. The only medical history of note is that she has been hypothyroid for 10 years and takes thyroxine 100 mg per day. She does not take any alcohol, smoke or use recreational drugs. On lab investigation FSH level is 45 IU/L. what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Premature ovarian failure

  • This woman has symptoms of amenorrhoea as well as hypo-oestrogenic vasomotor symptomsand vaginal dryness. The diagnosis is of premature menopause (premature ovarian failure),confirmed by the very high FSH levels.
  • Premature ovarian failure is defined as cessation of due to loss of function of the ovaries before the age of 40 years
  • FSH and LH will be high (FSH > 20)
  • Estradiol levels will be low.  

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Stopping progesterone pills does not cause a delay in return to fertility. Amongst all temporary contraceptives, Inj DMPA causes a delayed return to fertility
  • Option B: In Sheehan syndrome, she would have had reduced FSH levels asn it is due to pituitary failure. Here the FSH is high meaning it is an ovarian cause. 
  • Option D: Hypothyroidism is also unlikely in this scenario as she has been taking her medication and hypothyroidism will present as intolerance to cold (inability to stay warm). Hyperthyroidism may present with sweating and hot flushes. FSH levels will not be high in hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • Premature ovarian failure is defined as cessation of due to loss of function of the ovaries before the age of 40 years
    • FSH and LH will be high (FSH > 20)
    • Estradiol levels will be low
